comments:
I work with Eclipse3.0.1. It ran OK, till suddenly it stop working - 
it just refuse to load!
I get an error message that says that an error had occurred
and that I can find the log file at D:\Documents but I don?t have such a 
directory so I can't find the .log file!

I found the log. It was located in a different directory than the one that was 
specified in the error message (That is a bug too)

Where was the log actually (please provide complete path)?

The location of the log file is:
D:\Documents and Settings\pbobing\.eclipse\org.eclipse.platform_3.0.1
\configuration

Ok, the problem with the truncated message is a known issue (we confused by the
whitespaces) and has already been reported.

It seems you are in a shared install setup, right? This explains why the user
home dir (under Documents and Settings) is being used.

1) Where is Eclipse installed? 
2) Are you the only person managing Eclipse's install location?
2) Have you (or the person that owns the Eclipse install) updated Eclipse, or
added new plug-ins around the time you started seeing this?

As a potential workaround:
- rename D:\Documents and
Settings\pbobing\.eclipse\org.eclipse.platform_3.0.1\configuration to 
D:\Documents and
Settings\pbobing\.eclipse\org.eclipse.platform_3.0.1\configuration.bak
- try running Eclipse again

Does it work?

Firt of all - your workaround had worked !
Secondly, you are right.We are using a shared install setup.
Eclipse is installed on our intranet and is managed only by me.
Every one copy a link to eclipse.exe, that is on our site, and use it from his 
local machine.
I didn't update the installation or the plug-ins when it occurred, but the 
person that this problem happened to him had added a new plug-in to his private 
plug-ins (We uses the links method to declare the plug-ins location. One of the 
links is to the c:\Program Files\Eclipse3\usr where each user can add his own 
plug-ins and features).
After he added the plug-in he succeeded to open Eclipse, saw the new plug-in, 
and everything was ok till the Eclipse stuck to him. He than closed Eclipse and 
tried to reopen it- but he couldn't - he could get only the error message !
This had happened even after reboot, after removing the plug in, after removing 
the plug-in directory, after removing the user private plug-ins option and even 
after deleting the Eclipse link and create a new link.

The configuration got into an inconsistent state, maybe due to the fact that
Eclipse did not shutdown properly during the session the installed some plug-ins.

Could you provide two ZIP files, one containing the org.eclipse.osgi and
org.eclipse.update directories under configuration.bak (the corrupted one), and
the other containing the same directories under configuration (the valid one,
just created)? Thanks.

I wanted to add that the workaround that was suggested is working, but only 
partial: We need to delete the configuration directory each time we open 
Eclipse and it isn't convenience at all..

Created an attachment (id=14997)
contains the org.eclipse.osgi and org.eclipse.update directories

Created an attachment (id=14998)
contains the configuration.bak org.eclipse.osgi and org.eclipse.update
directories

The attachment for the new configuration directory does not contain the
org.eclipse.osgi subdir. And the attachment for the configuration.bak directory
does not seem to contain all files and directories under org.eclipse.osgi (I
would expect seeing a manifests directory there containing several *.MF files).

Please ensure you are zipping all files and directories inside org.eclipse.osgi
and org.eclipse.update.

Please reopen when you have news on this PR. Without the information requested
there is not much we can do to investigate the problem. Thanks.

Created an attachment (id=15095)
The new configuration directory

The attachment for the new configuration directory does not contain the
org.eclipse.osgi subdir becuause this directory contains only the bundles
directory which is empty.

Created an attachment (id=15096)
The backup configuration directory

The attachment for the configuration.bak directory
contain all files under org.eclipse.osgi (the files are .bundledata, .state).
It doesn't contain the directory bundles because it empty.
I didn't find the manifests directory and any .MF files

The bug is reproduced - each time we open Eclipse it happens and we need to 
delete the configuration file in order to open Eclipse.
We can't work like that and people have started to despair from Eclipse..

Eclipse does not run if the bundle manifests are not being generated. It seems
they are being generated somewhere else. Or they are being deleted at some point.

Please execute these steps to produce information we can use to investigate the
problem (will attach the debug.options file soon):

1) delete the user-specific configuration area

2) run Eclipse using the command-line, with the following syntax:

cd <ECLIPSE_DIR>
<JAVA_HOME>\jre\bin\java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -debug
debug.options -consolelog > firstrun.output

3) once Eclipse starts up, go to Help -> About... -> Configuration Details...
and, after copying the contents to the clipboard, paste them into a file called
firstrun.config

4) Exit Eclipse

5) Run again with the same command-line, but redirecting the output now to
secondrun.output. This should fail (this is what this bug is about), right?

6) Please attach the three files (firstrun.output, firstrun.config and
secondrun.output) to this PR.

These steps are to be performed in the same machine/Eclipse install where the
problem happens. Thanks for your help and your patience.

Created an attachment (id=15144)
debug options file

Please store this file in the Eclipse directory. Thanks.

Created an attachment (id=15293)
This is the firstrun.output file

Created an attachment (id=15294)
This is the firstrun.output.config file

Created an attachment (id=15295)
This is the secondrun.output file

I don't know how and why but the second run succeeded !
In fact, the bug doesn't happen again (at least not in that computer)

It seems you didn't see comment 16. I know that I was not clear, but you should
add that file (debug.options) to the Eclipse install before performing the steps
I described in comment 15.

Could you please repeat those steps *after* adding the debug.options file to the
Eclipse directory? That will produce the output I was looking for.

Note that you should do that for an Eclipse install where the problem still happens.

I saw comment 16. I added the file debug.options to the Eclipse install 
directory (the directory that contains the plugins,features, configuration 
directories) before performing the steps you had described in comment 15.

The results I added in commnemts 17-20 where after adding the file !

Are you sure you changed the current directory to be "eclipse". The one
containing  eclipse.exe and the debug.options file given to you?

Yes.
The directory that contains the eclipse.exe and the debug.options file ia 
named 'eclipse'.
This is the full path tot he directory:
\\isfiler1\work1\SWproj\SDE\Development-tools\Eclipse\eclipse

The debug.options file should have been found, but it is not. Besides the
absence of the expected debug information, the following message in the first
block of lines in the *.output files you generated show that the file could not
be found:

Debug options:
    file:/W:/SWproj/SDE/Development-tools/Eclipse/eclipse/debug.options not found

I am getting out of clues here. I don't understand why that would be happening.
I would move the debug.options file to a local, more conventional location
(c:\temp, for instance) and change the command line to point to the new location
of the debug.options file, for example:

cd <ECLIPSE_DIR>
<JAVA_HOME>\jre\bin\java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -debug
c:\temp\debug.options -consolelog > firstrun.output

firstrun.output file

Created an attachment (id=15663)
secondrun.output file

1. I did as you said and ran the debug.option from c:\temp (for the first and
second run):
<JAVA_HOME>\jre\bin\java -cp startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -debug
c:\temp\debug.options -consolelog > firstrun.output
2. the bug didn't happen when in the second run

Guy, are you saying that for every client previously having problems with 2nd
startup, whenever you try to reproduce the problem according to the steps
described in comment 15, the problem actually goes away?

I am not saying that the problem goes away for every client previously having 
problems with 2nd startup, whenever I am trying to reproduce the problem 
according to the steps described in comment 15.
I am just saying that for the client I checked, the bug doesn't happen again 
after I did the steps described in comment 15.

I said that because the two times you tried gathering information about the
problem (comment 19 and comment 27) you were not able to reproduce the problem.
Unless you were using the same machine in both times. If that is the case,
please run the test on a machine you know the problem persists. What we are
trying to do is to collect information on a failing install. Without this
information, there is not much that can be done in our side (since you cannot
reproduce the problem). Thanks.

This is just a friendly reminder <g>. Please reopen when you have the requested
information. Thanks.
